Day 11 of #50daysofkaggle

Roadmap to tidymodels

Titanic dataset in R
kaggle
R
Author

Ramakant

Published

February 20, 2023

On this page

  • Data reading and cleaning
  • Model Building
  • Testing accuracy

Till now I practiced creating classification predictions on the Titanic dataset using KNN, DT and SVM algorithms. As per Kaggle, my submission got a score of 77%. Now I’m going to try these approaches in R.

steps to do : data reading > cleaning > replacing NA > splitting > model using Decision Trees> comparing results

Data reading and cleaning

df <-  read_csv(unz(ziplocation, "train.csv"))

Code 
df_n <- df %>% 
  select_if(is.numeric) %>% 
  select(-PassengerId)

df_n <- df_n %>% 
  bind_cols(Sex = df$Sex, Embarked = df$Embarked) 
glimpse(df)

Code 
#finding null values

df_n$Survived <- as.factor(df_n$Survived)

df_n %>%  
  summarise_all(~ sum(is.na(.)))
# A tibble: 1 × 8
  Survived Pclass   Age SibSp Parch  Fare   Sex Embarked
     <int>  <int> <int> <int> <int> <int> <int>    <int>
1        0      0   177     0     0     0     0        2

Finding the mean of Age values and replacing NA values in Age

Code 
median(df_n$Age, na.rm = T)
[1] 28
Code 
df_n <- df_n %>% 
  mutate(Age = replace_na(Age, median(Age, na.rm = T)))

df_n %>% summarise_all(~sum(is.na(.)))
# A tibble: 1 × 8
  Survived Pclass   Age SibSp Parch  Fare   Sex Embarked
     <int>  <int> <int> <int> <int> <int> <int>    <int>
1        0      0     0     0     0     0     0        2

Model Building

Splitting the data into train & test

Code 
df_split <- initial_split(df_n, prop = 0.8)
train <- training(df_split)
test <- testing(df_split)

df_split
<Training/Testing/Total>
<712/179/891>

creating the recipe

Code 
show_engines("decision_tree") #shows the list of engines & modes
# A tibble: 5 × 2
  engine mode          
  <chr>  <chr>         
1 rpart  classification
2 rpart  regression    
3 C5.0   classification
4 spark  classification
5 spark  regression
Code 
dt_recipe <- recipe(Survived ~ ., data = df_n) %>% 
  #reomving NA rows in Embarked columns
  step_naomit(Embarked) %>% 
  #replacing NA values in Age with median Age
  step_mutate_at(Age, fn = ~ replace_na(Age, median(Age, na.rm = T))) %>% 
  step_dummy(all_nominal_predictors()) %>% 
  step_normalize(all_numeric_predictors()) 
  
  
  
  # %>% step_mutate_at(Survived, fn = ~as_factor(Survived))

dt_recipe
── Recipe ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
── Inputs 
Number of variables by role
outcome:   1
predictor: 7
── Operations 
• Removing rows with NA values in: Embarked
• Variable mutation for: Age
• Dummy variables from: all_nominal_predictors()
• Centering and scaling for: all_numeric_predictors()
Code 
tidy(dt_recipe)
# A tibble: 4 × 6
  number operation type      trained skip  id             
   <int> <chr>     <chr>     <lgl>   <lgl> <chr>          
1      1 step      naomit    FALSE   TRUE  naomit_v5LGU   
2      2 step      mutate_at FALSE   FALSE mutate_at_4Ocnv
3      3 step      dummy     FALSE   FALSE dummy_Sfkr8    
4      4 step      normalize FALSE   FALSE normalize_5Lshi
Code 
dt_model <- decision_tree(mode = "classification", tree_depth = 3) %>% 
  set_engine("rpart")

dt_model %>% translate()
Decision Tree Model Specification (classification)

Main Arguments:
  tree_depth = 3

Computational engine: rpart 

Model fit template:
rpart::rpart(formula = missing_arg(), data = missing_arg(), weights = missing_arg(), 
    maxdepth = 3)

Creating a workflow based on the model > fitting data > predicting the results

Code 
dt_wf <- workflow() %>%
  add_model(dt_model) %>% 
  add_recipe(dt_recipe)


dt_predict <- predict(fit(dt_wf, data = train), test)

test_n <- bind_cols(test, dt_predict)
test_n <- test_n %>% 
  rename(dt_yhat = .pred_class)

predicted_table <- test_n %>% 
  select(Survived, dt_yhat) 

#this table converts factors to numeric values
predicted_table2 <- test_n %>% 
  select(Survived, dt_yhat) %>% 
#convert factor to numeric
 mutate(across(where(is.factor), as.numeric)) %>%
#conversion takes values 1 & 2 instead of 0 & 1, hence correcting back
 mutate(across(1:2, ~.x -1))

predicted_table2 %>% rmse(dt_yhat, Survived)
# A tibble: 1 × 3
  .metric .estimator .estimate
  <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
1 rmse    standard       0.442

Testing accuracy

As mentioned in the TMRW documentation for binary classification metrics, we will try creating the confusion matrix and checking accuracy

Code 
predicted_table
# A tibble: 179 × 2
   Survived dt_yhat
   <fct>    <fct>  
 1 1        1      
 2 1        1      
 3 1        0      
 4 1        0      
 5 0        1      
 6 0        0      
 7 0        1      
 8 0        0      
 9 1        1      
10 1        1      
# … with 169 more rows
Code 
conf_mat(predicted_table, truth = Survived, estimate = dt_yhat)
          Truth
Prediction  0  1
         0 95 22
         1 13 49
Code 
accuracy(predicted_table, truth = Survived, estimate = dt_yhat)
# A tibble: 1 × 3
  .metric  .estimator .estimate
  <chr>    <chr>          <dbl>
1 accuracy binary         0.804
Code 
classification_metrics <- metric_set(accuracy, f_meas)

predicted_table %>% 
  classification_metrics(truth = Survived, estimate = dt_yhat)
# A tibble: 2 × 3
  .metric  .estimator .estimate
  <chr>    <chr>          <dbl>
1 accuracy binary         0.804
2 f_meas   binary         0.844
